Al embers of the M aryland Editorial Association, and of both
Houses of the Maryland Legislature, were guests of the Johns Hop-kins University at a dinner given
last Wednesday night at the Merchants' Club for the purpose of discussing the proposed appropriation
of $1,500,000 by the Legislature to
aid Hopkins in establishing a technological school at Homewood.
During the afternoon the editors
and legislators, accompanied by the
Hopkins trustees and several members of the faculty, made an inspection tour of the Homewood
grounds. Before going to Homewood, President Ira Remsen made
an address, explaining the plans for
the proposed technological school,
and the members of the party spent
a short time in going over the present University buildings.
Dr. Michel I. Pupin, head of the
department of electrical engineering
at Columbia University, New York,
was the principal speaker at the
dinner at the Merchants' Club. He
made an eloquent appeal for the
establishment of a technological
school by Hopkins, and pointed out
how advantageous it would be for
the South.
Col. William S. Powell, of Ellicott City, president of the Maryland Editorial Association, told of
the impetus which would be given
the manufacturing interests of
Maryland by the establishment of
a technological school. Other speakers were: Messrs. R. Brent Keyser.
William L. Marbury, B. Howell
Griswold, Jr., and Senator Hammond of Harford county.

The University track team won
the point trophy at the annual
Georgetown indoor meet in Washington on Saturday night, with a
total of 19 points, with Virginia
second, 15 points; Georgetown
third, io points, and Princeton,
Yale, and Cornell, each 5 points.
Hopkins score was consistent all
through the evening, receiving
points in seven events. The team
has developed the last week into
a well-balanced aggregation, which
is evident from the fact that no
man scored more than once.
The feature performance was
Captain Lee's race in the mile. He
started from scratch with J. P.
Jones, of Cornell, the outdoor record holder for the distance. The
time was 4.304, and at the finish
Lee was so close that he could have,
touched Jones with his outstretched
arm. The result shows the sterling
quality of Lee's running this year.
Dignan won the shot-put in good
form; distance, 43 feet 3 inches.
Horrax took second place in the
open handicap hurdles from scratch,
and also second in the invitation
hurdles. The latter race did not
count for the point trophy. Uhler,
the best man from the freshman
*class, did excellent work in the 44o
open, and won second medal after
the race had been run in heats. Catlin came in a close second in the
open half mile. Two third-place
medals came to Tappan in the high
jump and the pole-vault.
The results of the meet were
more or less a surprise to the crowd
of supporters Hopkins had at the
games. Work hitherto has been
very mediocre, indeed, and Hopkins
has hardly held her own in the previous indoor meets of the winter;
but the work of the coaches since
the Armory meet has been centered
upon the development of some
twelve men in order to have as
many as possible win points, instead of depending- upon two or
three stars. A well balanced team
went, therefore, to Washington on
Saturday, and seven of the members contributed to the score that
won the meet. One first place,
four second places, and two third
places netted the nineteen - points,.
which is four more than Virginia
won. All of this gives promise of
a strong team for the spring- meets
which begin after the Easter vacation. The schedule is a good one,
dual meets with the Navy at Ail-

President Remsen's Plans.

President Remsen announced last
week that he had completed his
plans for the trips he is to take
this week to address various Johns
Hopkins alumni Associations at their
annual meetings. He''is always in
great demand for these meetings,
because the men who have been
away from college for some time
are always anxious to receive news
of it from an authoritative source.
Only last SaturdaY he went to Boston to address the New England
Alumni Association. He characterized their meeting as one of the
best he had ever attended. This
took plae in Boston on Saturday
night. About fifty members of the
Association from all over New England were present. Saturday noon

BALTIMORE, MD., MAR. 4, 1912
Dr. Gildersleeve's Lectures.

We wish to congratulate Professor Gildersleeve upon the admirable
series of lectures which he brought
to a close last Saturday morning.
We wish to congratulate him upon
the robust vigor and youthful fire
which enabled him to hold the unflagging attention of his hearers
and to revive before them so vividly
the passions and sentiments of men
who lived two thousand years ago.
An appreciation of literature—the
faculty of viewing words not merely as words but as the vehicles of
the aspirations and feelings of men
—is a rare gift among philologists
and is the true test between the
scholar and the pedant; in everything that he has ever written, Professor Gildersleeve has shown that
he possesses that gift. •
The one thing which the interpreter of literature needs above all
others is enthusiasm—the ability to
abandon himself completely to the
mood of the author whom he is
interpreting—and enthusiasm often
fails with age; but in the course
of lectures which he has just completed, Professor Gildersleeve has
exhibited that quality in a degree
in,, which it is not possessed by
many a man of thirty. May we
have the pleasure of hearing many
similar courses from so distinguished a scholar; and we wish to
take this opportunity of expressing
our admiration for one who is the
Grand Old Man of Hopkins and
who occupies a lofty seat among
the "di majorunt gentium" of the
world of letters.
Commencement Week.

One step was taken in the right
direction when President Lee, on
Thursday, appointed a committee of
seniors to arrange for a more adequate Commencement in June. A
number of suggestions have been
made, and it will be the duty of this

Several months ago we published
an editorial explaining why is was
impossible for THE NEWS-LETTER
Board to get as many alumni notes
as we would like to publish. We
asked you, our alumni subscribers,
to help us and your fellow alumni
by sending in any items of interest
you might have, about either yourselves or your friends. Many alumni were kind enough to avail themselves of this opportunity. We
thanked them then by letter, and
now wish to thank them again, publicly.
But, as before, we have run dry
and now we come to you a second
time. Won't three or four hundred of you who have been reading the paper this year—and we
hope; enjoying it—emulate the dozen or so of your fellow alumni who
have already done so, and send us
in a few items. Even a single one
will be helpful. Don't be bashful.
Send in something about yourselves—the other "boys" are interested in you. It doesn't need to
be a world-important event; the appearance of some future Hopkins
alumnus or alumna, an advance in
position, a trip abroad, or any other
thing that you would be interested
in hearing about one of your classmates.
We want the paper to be of interest to every Hopkins man, wherever located, and this is one of the
means of so doing. Won't you help
with a little co-operation?

THE NEWS—LETTER, MARCH 4, 1912.

4

BALTIMORE LAW SCHOOL

Johns Hopkins Alumni at University
Commons.

849 N. HOWARD ST.

The Virginia-Johns Hopkins Alumni Association gave its annual
banquet Thursday night in the University Commons. A number of
distinguished alumni from a distance were present to add to the
success of the occasion.
• The principal speech of the evening was delivered by Professor
Bloomfield, holder of the chair of
Sanskrit in Johns Hopkins University. Speeches were also made by
President Hall Canter, professor of
chemistry at Randolph-Macon College; Professor J. H. Latane, of
Washington and Lee, former president of the Association; Professor
T. J. Stubbs, Jr., of Richmond College; Tax Expert D. S. Freeman,
and Mr. R. C. Lewis, of Philadelphia. Among the twenty or more
Hopkins alumni in the Virginia faculty, Professors Bird, Lefevre, and
Mallet were conspicuous.
The Association has been established some twelve years in this
State, and counts among its members many of the foremost educators in Virginia.
After the election of officers, the
Association, according to its custom, wired to President Remsen of
Hopkins an expression of its loyalty
and good wishes. At the same hour
at whieh the banquet was held here,
the Hopkins celebrated its founder's
day in Baltimore.—University of
Virginia College Topics.

The proof-reader on a small Middle-Western daily was a woman of
great precision and extreme propriety. One day a reporter succeeded in getting into type an item
about "Willie Brown, the boy who
was burned in the West End by a
live wire."
On the following day the reporter found on his desk a frigid note
asking: "Which is the west end
of a boy?"
It took only an instant to reply,
"The end the son sets on, of
course"—Ladies' Home Journal.

Al embers of the M aryland Editorial Association, and of both
Houses of the Maryland Legislature, were guests of the Johns Hop-kins University at a dinner given
last Wednesday night at the Merchants' Club for the purpose of discussing the proposed appropriation
of $1,500,000 by the Legislature to
aid Hopkins in establishing a technological school at Homewood.
During the afternoon the editors
and legislators, accompanied by the
Hopkins trustees and several members of the faculty, made an inspection tour of the Homewood
grounds. Before going to Homewood, President Ira Remsen made
an address, explaining the plans for
the proposed technological school,
and the members of the party spent
a short time in going over the present University buildings.
Dr. Michel I. Pupin, head of the
department of electrical engineering
at Columbia University, New York,
was the principal speaker at the
dinner at the Merchants' Club. He
made an eloquent appeal for the
establishment of a technological
school by Hopkins, and pointed out
how advantageous it would be for
the South.
Col. William S. Powell, of Ellicott City, president of the Maryland Editorial Association, told of
the impetus which would be given
the manufacturing interests of
Maryland by the establishment of
a technological school. Other speakers were: Messrs. R. Brent Keyser.
William L. Marbury, B. Howell
Griswold, Jr., and Senator Hammond of Harford county.

The University track team won
the point trophy at the annual
Georgetown indoor meet in Washington on Saturday night, with a
total of 19 points, with Virginia
second, 15 points; Georgetown
third, io points, and Princeton,
Yale, and Cornell, each 5 points.
Hopkins score was consistent all
through the evening, receiving
points in seven events. The team
has developed the last week into
a well-balanced aggregation, which
is evident from the fact that no
man scored more than once.
The feature performance was
Captain Lee's race in the mile. He
started from scratch with J. P.
Jones, of Cornell, the outdoor record holder for the distance. The
time was 4.304, and at the finish
Lee was so close that he could have,
touched Jones with his outstretched
arm. The result shows the sterling
quality of Lee's running this year.
Dignan won the shot-put in good
form; distance, 43 feet 3 inches.
Horrax took second place in the
open handicap hurdles from scratch,
and also second in the invitation
hurdles. The latter race did not
count for the point trophy. Uhler,
the best man from the freshman
*class, did excellent work in the 44o
open, and won second medal after
the race had been run in heats. Catlin came in a close second in the
open half mile. Two third-place
medals came to Tappan in the high
jump and the pole-vault.
The results of the meet were
more or less a surprise to the crowd
of supporters Hopkins had at the
games. Work hitherto has been
very mediocre, indeed, and Hopkins
has hardly held her own in the previous indoor meets of the winter;
but the work of the coaches since
the Armory meet has been centered
upon the development of some
twelve men in order to have as
many as possible win points, instead of depending- upon two or
three stars. A well balanced team
went, therefore, to Washington on
Saturday, and seven of the members contributed to the score that
won the meet. One first place,
four second places, and two third
places netted the nineteen - points,.
which is four more than Virginia
won. All of this gives promise of
a strong team for the spring- meets
which begin after the Easter vacation. The schedule is a good one,
dual meets with the Navy at Ail-

President Remsen's Plans.

President Remsen announced last
week that he had completed his
plans for the trips he is to take
this week to address various Johns
Hopkins alumni Associations at their
annual meetings. He''is always in
great demand for these meetings,
because the men who have been
away from college for some time
are always anxious to receive news
of it from an authoritative source.
Only last SaturdaY he went to Boston to address the New England
Alumni Association. He characterized their meeting as one of the
best he had ever attended. This
took plae in Boston on Saturday
night. About fifty members of the
Association from all over New England were present. Saturday noon

BALTIMORE, MD., MAR. 4, 1912
Dr. Gildersleeve's Lectures.

We wish to congratulate Professor Gildersleeve upon the admirable
series of lectures which he brought
to a close last Saturday morning.
We wish to congratulate him upon
the robust vigor and youthful fire
which enabled him to hold the unflagging attention of his hearers
and to revive before them so vividly
the passions and sentiments of men
who lived two thousand years ago.
An appreciation of literature—the
faculty of viewing words not merely as words but as the vehicles of
the aspirations and feelings of men
—is a rare gift among philologists
and is the true test between the
scholar and the pedant; in everything that he has ever written, Professor Gildersleeve has shown that
he possesses that gift. •
The one thing which the interpreter of literature needs above all
others is enthusiasm—the ability to
abandon himself completely to the
mood of the author whom he is
interpreting—and enthusiasm often
fails with age; but in the course
of lectures which he has just completed, Professor Gildersleeve has
exhibited that quality in a degree
in,, which it is not possessed by
many a man of thirty. May we
have the pleasure of hearing many
similar courses from so distinguished a scholar; and we wish to
take this opportunity of expressing
our admiration for one who is the
Grand Old Man of Hopkins and
who occupies a lofty seat among
the "di majorunt gentium" of the
world of letters.
Commencement Week.

One step was taken in the right
direction when President Lee, on
Thursday, appointed a committee of
seniors to arrange for a more adequate Commencement in June. A
number of suggestions have been
made, and it will be the duty of this

Several months ago we published
an editorial explaining why is was
impossible for THE NEWS-LETTER
Board to get as many alumni notes
as we would like to publish. We
asked you, our alumni subscribers,
to help us and your fellow alumni
by sending in any items of interest
you might have, about either yourselves or your friends. Many alumni were kind enough to avail themselves of this opportunity. We
thanked them then by letter, and
now wish to thank them again, publicly.
But, as before, we have run dry
and now we come to you a second
time. Won't three or four hundred of you who have been reading the paper this year—and we
hope; enjoying it—emulate the dozen or so of your fellow alumni who
have already done so, and send us
in a few items. Even a single one
will be helpful. Don't be bashful.
Send in something about yourselves—the other "boys" are interested in you. It doesn't need to
be a world-important event; the appearance of some future Hopkins
alumnus or alumna, an advance in
position, a trip abroad, or any other
thing that you would be interested
in hearing about one of your classmates.
We want the paper to be of interest to every Hopkins man, wherever located, and this is one of the
means of so doing. Won't you help
with a little co-operation?

THE NEWS—LETTER, MARCH 4, 1912.

4

BALTIMORE LAW SCHOOL

Johns Hopkins Alumni at University
Commons.

849 N. HOWARD ST.

The Virginia-Johns Hopkins Alumni Association gave its annual
banquet Thursday night in the University Commons. A number of
distinguished alumni from a distance were present to add to the
success of the occasion.
• The principal speech of the evening was delivered by Professor
Bloomfield, holder of the chair of
Sanskrit in Johns Hopkins University. Speeches were also made by
President Hall Canter, professor of
chemistry at Randolph-Macon College; Professor J. H. Latane, of
Washington and Lee, former president of the Association; Professor
T. J. Stubbs, Jr., of Richmond College; Tax Expert D. S. Freeman,
and Mr. R. C. Lewis, of Philadelphia. Among the twenty or more
Hopkins alumni in the Virginia faculty, Professors Bird, Lefevre, and
Mallet were conspicuous.
The Association has been established some twelve years in this
State, and counts among its members many of the foremost educators in Virginia.
After the election of officers, the
Association, according to its custom, wired to President Remsen of
Hopkins an expression of its loyalty
and good wishes. At the same hour
at whieh the banquet was held here,
the Hopkins celebrated its founder's
day in Baltimore.—University of
Virginia College Topics.

The proof-reader on a small Middle-Western daily was a woman of
great precision and extreme propriety. One day a reporter succeeded in getting into type an item
about "Willie Brown, the boy who
was burned in the West End by a
live wire."
On the following day the reporter found on his desk a frigid note
asking: "Which is the west end
of a boy?"
It took only an instant to reply,
"The end the son sets on, of
course"—Ladies' Home Journal.
